{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2018}} {{About|a Sikh and Hindu festival|the unrelated Buddhist festival|Vesak}} {{infobox holiday | holiday_name = Vaisakhi, Baisakhi
{{lang-pa|ਵਿਸਾਖੀ}} | image = Handsworth Vaisakhi.jpg | caption = Vaisakhi is a Sikh new year festival, and the birthday of its Khalsa Panth | nickname = Baisakh, Vaisakh | observedby = Sikhs | observances = Prayers, [[procession]]s, raising of the [[Nishan Sahib]] flag, Fairs. | celebrations = Parades and Nagar Kirtan, Fairs, Amrit Sanchaar (baptism) for new Khalsa | type = Sikh |longtype = religious, cultural |date2018 = Sat, 14 April{{cite web |url=https://www.india.gov.in/calendar/calendar.php?date=2018-04 |title=April 2018 Official Central Government Holiday Calendar |accessdate=17 December 2017 |publisher = Government of India}} |date2019 = Sat, 13 April |date2020 = Mon, 13 April | significance = Sikh New Year, Harvest festival, birth of the [[Khalsa]] }} '''Vaisakhi''' ([[IAST]]: {{IAST|visākhī}}), also known as '''Baisakhi''', '''Vaishakhi''', or '''Vasakhi''' is a historical and religious festival in [[Sikhism]] and [[Hinduism]]. It is usually celebrated on 13 or 14 April every year.{{cite book|author=Harjinder Singh|title=Vaisakhi|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bCReCAAAQBAJ&pg=PA2|publisher=Akaal Publishers|page=2}}{{cite book|author1=K.R. Gupta|author2=Amita Gupta|title=Concise Encyclopaedia of India|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9dNOT9iYxcMC&pg=PA998 |year=2006|publisher=Atlantic Publishers|isbn=978-81-269-0639-0|page=998}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/naperville-sun/community/chi-ugc-article-sikh-religious-society-organizes-two-day-con-2017-11-18-story.html|title=Chicago Tribune|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=}} Vaisakhi marks the Sikh new year{{cite book|author=Cath Senker|title=My Sikh Year|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PsQozVTKW44C&pg=PA10|year=2007|publisher=The Rosen Publishing Group|isbn=978-1-4042-3733-9|page=10}}, Quote: "Vaisakhi is the most important mela. It marks the Sikh New Year. At Vaisakhi, Sikhs remember how their community, the Khalsa, first began." and commemorates the formation of [[Khalsa]] panth of warriors under [[Guru Gobind Singh]] in 1699.BBC Religions (2009), [http://www.bbc.co.uk/religion/religions/sikhism/holydays/vaisakhi.shtml Vaisakhi and the Khalsa]{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WT2odZ7_d7MC&pg=PA192|title=South Asian Religions on Display: Religious Processions in South Asia and in the Diaspora|author=Knut A. Jacobsen|publisher=Routledge|year=2008|isbn=978-1-134-07459-4|page=192}}, '''Quote:''' "Baisakhi is also a Hindu festival, but for the Sikhs, it celebrates the foundation of the Khalsa in 1699." It is additionally a spring harvest festival for the Sikhs. Vaisakhi observes major events in the history of Sikhism and the [[Indian subcontinent]] that happened in the [[Punjab region]].{{cite book|author1=William Owen Cole|author2=Piara Singh Sambhi|title=The Sikhs: Their Religious Beliefs and Practices|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zIC_MgJ5RMUC |year=1995|publisher=Sussex Academic Press|isbn=978-1-898723-13-4|pages=135–136}} The significance of Vaisakhi as a major Sikh festival marking the birth of Sikh order started after the persecution and execution of [[Guru Tegh Bahadur]] for refusing to convert to Islam under the orders of the Mughal Emperor [[Aurangzeb]]. This triggered the coronation of the tenth Guru of Sikhism and the historic formation of [[Khalsa]], both on the Vaisakhi day.{{cite book | last=Seiple | first=Chris | title=The Routledge handbook of religion and security | publisher=Routledge | location=New York | year=2013 | isbn=978-0-415-66744-9 | page=96}}{{cite book|author=Harkirat S. Hansra|title=Liberty at Stake, Sikhs: the Most Visible|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RDlMUfGiEO8C&pg=PA28 |year=2007|publisher=iUniverse|isbn=978-0-595-43222-6 |pages=28–29}} Vaisakhi was also the day when colonial British empire officials committed the [[Jallianwala Bagh massacre]] on a gathering, an event influential to the Indian movement against colonial rule.S. R. Bakshi, Sita Ram Sharma, S. Gajnani (1998) Parkash Singh Badal: Chief Minister of Punjab. APH Publishing [https://books.google.com/books?id=cyebnJdCFlEC&pg=PA208 pages 208–209] On Vaisakhi, Gurdwaras are decorated and hold [[kirtan]]s, Sikhs visit and bathe in lakes or rivers before visiting local Gurdwaras, community fairs and ''nagar kirtan'' processions are held, and people gather to socialize and share festive foods.{{cite book|author1=Jonathan H. X. Lee|author2=Kathleen M. Nadeau|title=Encyclopedia of Asian American Folklore and Folklife |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9BrfLWdeISoC&pg=PA1012 |year=2011|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-0-313-35066-5|pages=1012–1013}} For many Hindus, the festival is their traditional solar new year, a harvest festival, an occasion to bathe in sacred rivers such as Ganges, Jhelum and Kaveri, visit temples, meet friends and party over festive foods. This festival in Hinduism is known by various regional names.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IKqOUfqt4cIC&pg=PA479|title=Traditional Festivals: A Multicultural Encyclopedia|author=Christian Roy|publisher=ABC-CLIO|year=2005|isbn=978-1-57607-089-5|pages=479–480}} ==Date== Vaisakhi is traditionally observed on 13 or 14 April, every year. The festival is important to both Sikhs and Hindus. The festival coincides with other new year festivals celebrated on the first day of Vaisakh in other regions of the [[Indian Subcontinent]] such as [[Pohela Boishakh]], [[Bohag Bihu]], [[Vishu]], [[Puthandu]] among others.Crump, William D. (2014), [https://books.google.com/books?id=cDTfCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA114 Encyclopedia of New Year's Holidays Worldwide], MacFarland, page 114 ==Spelling and pronunciation== The spelling varies with region. In Punjab region, ''Vaisakhi'' is common, but in the [[Doabi]] and [[Malwi dialect|Malwai]] dialects, speakers often substitute a ''b'' for a ''v''.{{Cite web |url=http://punjabrevenue.nic.in/gaz_gdr5.htm |title=Archived copy |access-date=26 November 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304123940/http://punjabrevenue.nic.in/gaz_gdr5.htm |archive-date=4 March 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} The spelling used depends on the dialect of the writer.{{Cite web|url=https://drive.google.com/file/d/1CB_aQY5TcY-oJ6GwVjx55Lqd153eihGl/view?usp=sharing|title=Pronunciation of Vaisakhi|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} ==Sikhism== {{Sikhism sidebar}} {{Main|Khalsa}} [[File:Vaisakhi Sikh festival in Birmingham 2013.jpg|thumb|left|Vaisakhi celebrations in the United Kingdom]] ===History=== Vaisakhi is one of the three traditionally Hindu festivals chosen by [[Guru Amar Das]] in which Sikhs were to congregate and celebrate together (the others being [[Maha Shivaratri]] and [[Diwali]]).{{cite book|author1=William Owen Cole|author2=Piara Singh Sambhi|title=The Sikhs: Their Religious Beliefs and Practices|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zIC_MgJ5RMUC&pg=PA135|year=1995|publisher=Sussex Academic Press|isbn=978-1-898723-13-4|pages=135–136}}, '''Quote:''' "Since the time of Guru Amar Das it has been customary for Sikhs to assemble before their Guru on three of the most important Hindu festival occasions – Vaisakhi, Divali and Maha Shivaratri". The alternative view is that Guru Amar Das chose [[Makar Sankranti|Maghi]], instead of Maha Shivaratri.Fauja Singh, Gurbachan Singh Talib (1975), Punjabi University [https://books.google.com/books?id=7g0eAAAAMAAJ Guru Tegh Bahadur: Martyr and Teacher]H. S. Singha (2000), Hemkunt Press [https://books.google.com/books?id=gqIbJz7vMn0C&pg=PA16 The Encyclopedia of Sikhism (over 1000 Entries)] page 16 Subsequent events gave a new meaning to the festival which is, in part, a remembrance of the foundation of the Khalsa Sikh order which started after the ninth [[Guru Tegh Bahadur]] was persecuted and then beheaded under the orders of the Mughal Emperor [[Aurangzeb]], after he stood up for freedom of religious practice and refused to convert to Islam. The guru's martyrdom triggered the coronation of the tenth and last Guru of Sikhism, and the formation of the ''sant-sipahi'' group of [[Khalsa]],{{cite book|last=Chanchreek|first=Jain|title=Encyclopaedia of Great Festivals|year=2007|publisher=Shree Publishers & Distributors|isbn=9788183291910|page=142}}{{cite book|last=Dugga|first=Kartar|title=Maharaja Ranjit Singh: The Last to Lay Arms|year=2001|publisher=Abhinav Publications|isbn=9788170174103|page=33}} both on the Vaisakhi day.{{cite book | author=Pashaura Singh and Louis Fenech | title=The Oxford handbook of Sikh studies | publisher=Oxford University Press | location=Oxford, UK | year=2014 | isbn=978-0-19-969930-8 | pages=236–237}} The Vaisakhi festival Khalsa tradition started in the year 1699, as it is on this day that the 10th Guru of the Sikhs, [[Guru Gobind Singh]] laid down the foundation of the [[Khalsa|Panth Khalsa]], that is the Order of the Pure Ones, by baptizing Sikh warriors to defend religious freedoms.Pashaura Singh (2005), ''Understanding the Martyrdom of Guru Arjan'', Journal of Punjab Studies, 12(1), pages 29–62{{cite book|last1=Johar|first1=Surinder|title=Guru Gobind Singh: A Multi-faceted Personality|date=1999|publisher=M.D. Publications |isbn=978-8175330931|page=89}}{{cite book | title=History of Sikh Gurus Retold: 1606 -1708 | publisher=Atlantic Publishers | author=Singh Gandhi, Surjit | year=2008 | pages=676–677 | isbn=8126908572}} This gave rise to the Vaisakhi or Baisakhi festival being observed as a celebration of Khalsa panth formation and is also known as Khalsa Sirjana DivasLaws of the State of Illinois Enacted by the ... General Assembly at the Extra Session . (2013) State Printers. [https://books.google.com/books?id=adPXhc84ZMwC page 7772] and Khalsa Sajna Divas.Singh, Jagraj (2009) A Complete Guide to Sikhism. Unistar Books [https://books.google.com/books?id=rFm9_Jc1ykcC&pg=PA311 page 311] The festival is celebrated on Vaisakhi day (typically 14 April), since 1699. The Birth of the Khalsa Panth was either on 13 April 1699{{cite web|last1=Purewal|first1=Pal|title=Vaisakhi Dates Range According To Indian Ephemeris By Swamikannu Pillai – i.e. English Date on 1 Vaisakh Bikrami|url=http://www.purewal.biz/PastVaisakhiDates.pdf|website=www.purewal.biz|accessdate=13 April 2016}} or 30 March 1699.Kaur, Madanjit (2007). Unistar Books [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ZG4MycGdpjAC&pg=PA149 Guru Gobind Singh: Historical and Ideological Perspective], page 149 Since 2003, the Sikh Gurdwara Prabhandak Committee named it Baisakh (Vaisakh), making the first day of the second month of Vaisakh according to its new [[Nanakshahi calendar]].{{cite book|author=W. H. McLeod|title=The A to Z of Sikhism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vgixwfeCyDAC&pg=PA143|year=2009|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=978-0-8108-6344-6|pages=143–144}} A special celebration takes place at [[Talwandi Sabo]] (where [[Guru Gobind Singh]] stayed for nine months and completed the recompilation of the [[Guru Granth Sahib]]),{{cite news |title=Vaisakhi celebrated with fervour, gaiety|author=Tribune News service|newspaper=The Tribune, Chandigarh|date=14 April 2009}} in the [[Gurudwara]] at [[Anandpur Sahib]] the birthplace of the [[Khalsa]], and at the [[Harmandir Sahib|Golden Temple]] in [[Amritsar]]. ===Sikh New Year=== Vaisakhi has been the traditional Sikh New Year.{{cite book|author1=William Owen Cole|author2=Piara Singh Sambhi|title=The Sikhs: Their Religious Beliefs and Practices |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zIC_MgJ5RMUC&pg=PA63 |year=1995|publisher=Sussex Academic Press|isbn=978-1-898723-13-4|page=63}}, '''Quote:''' "The Sikh new year, Vaisakhi, occurs at Sangrand in April, usually on the thirteenth day."{{cite book|author=Nick Hunter|title=Celebrating Sikh Festivals|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QLBeCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA10|year=2016|publisher=Raintree|isbn=978-1-4062-9776-8|page=10}} According to the Khalsa sambat, the Khalsa calendar starts from the day of the creation of the Khalsa- 1 Vaisakh 1756 Bikrami (30 March 1699).Dogra, Ramesh Chander and Dogra, Urmila (2003) Page 248 The Sikh World: An Encyclopedic Survey of Sikh Religion and Culture. UBS Publishers Distributors Pvt Ltd {{ISBN|81-7476-443-7}} The festival has been traditionally observed in the [[Punjab region]].{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=d195AAAAMAAJ|title=Festivals in World Religions|first=Alan|last=Brown|year= 1986|publisher=Longman|accessdate=14 September 2016|via=Google Books}}Simon J Bronner (2015), Routledge [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=FvjqBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA1132 Encyclopedia of American Folklife], page 1132 ===Nagar Kirtan=== Sikhs communities organise processions called ''nagar kirtan'' (literally, "town hymn singing"). These are led by five khalsa who are dressed up as ''Panj Pyaare'', and the processions through the streets. The people who march sing, make music, sing hymns from the Sikh texts. Major processions also carry a copy of the [[Guru Granth Sahib]] in reverence. ===Harvest festival=== [[File:Common good.jpg|thumb|left|Two Sikh men celebrating Vaisakhi by giving away free sugarcane juice.]] [[File:Kothe-da-mela.jpg|thumb|Vaisakhi ''mela'']] Vaisakhi is a harvest festival for people of the [[Punjab region]].Bakshi, S. R. Sharma, Sita Ram (1998) Parkash Singh Badal: Chief Minister of Punjab [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=cyebnJdCFlEC&dq=baisakhi+punjabi+festival&source=gbs_navlinks_s] In the Punjab, Vaisakhi marks the ripening of the [[rabi crop|rabi]] harvest.Dogra, Ramesh Chander and Dogra, Urmila (2003) Page 49 The Sikh World: An Encyclopedic Survey of Sikh Religion and Culture. UBS Publishers Distributors Pvt Ltd {{ISBN|81-7476-443-7}} Vaisakhi also marks the Punjabi new year.Sainik Samachar: The Pictorial Weekly of the Armed Forces, Volume 33 (1986) Director of Public Relations, Ministry of Defence, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=t1jfAAAAMAAJ&q=Punjabi+new+year&dq=Punjabi+new+year&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjXluL21O3SAhUrI8AKHfVkAro4ChDoAQgoMAM] This day is observed as a thanksgiving day by farmers whereby farmers pay their tribute, thanking God for the abundant harvest and also praying for future prosperity.Dhillon, (2015) Janamsakhis: Ageless Stories, Timeless Values. Hay House [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=OXtVDgAAQBAJ&pg=PT197&dq=punjabi+calendar&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjkwr3R6OrSAhVEBMAKHduoBjYQ6AEIHzAB#v=onepage&q=punjabi%20calendar&f=false] The harvest festival is celebrated by Sikhs and Punjabi Hindus.Gupta, Surendra K. (1999) Indians in Thailand, Books India International [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=5rBuAAAAMAAJ&dq=baisakhi+harvest+punjab+hindus+and+sikhs&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=barley] Historically, during the early 20th century, Vaisakhi was a sacred day for Sikhs and Hindus and a secular festival for all Muslims and non-Muslims including Punjabi Christians.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=tNAxAQAAIAAJ&dq=baisakhi+harvest+punjab+hindus+and+sikhs&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=turbaned+sikhs Link: Indian Newsmagazine, Volume 30, Part 1 (1987)] In modern times, sometimes Christians participate in Baisakhi celebrations along with Sikhs and Hindus.Nahar, Emanual (2007) [Minority politics in India: role and impact of Christians in Punjab politics. Arun Pub. House. [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=vl9uAAAAMAAJ&dq=punjabi+christians+baisakhi+india&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=baisakhi+] ====Aawat pauni==== [[File:Bhangra 1.jpg|thumb|right|Bhangra dance on Vaisakhi is a Sikh tradition]] [[Aawat pauni]] is a tradition associated with harvesting, which involves people getting together to harvest the wheat. Drums are played while people work. At the end of the day, people sing [[Doha (poetry)|dohay]] to the tunes of the drum.Dr Singh, Sadhu (2010) Punjabi Boli Di Virasat.Chetna Prakashan. {{ISBN|817883618-1}} ====Fairs and dances==== The harvest festival is also characterized by the folk dance, [[Bhangra (dance)|Bhangra]] which traditionally is a harvest dance. Fairs or ''[[Mela]]s'' are held in many parts of [[Punjab, India]] to mark the new year and the harvesting season. Vaisakhi fairs take place in various places, including [[Jammu]] City, Kathua, Udhampur, Reasi and Samba,{{cite web|url=http://zeenews.india.com/news/jammu-and-kashmir/baisakhi-celebrated-with-fervour-gaiety-in-jk_1578749.html|title=Baisakhi celebrated with fervour, gaiety in J&K|date=14 April 2015|publisher=|accessdate=14 September 2016}} in the Pinjore complex near [[Chandigarh]],{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=7d3rX5jr1WQC&dq=haryana%20baisakhi&source=gbs_navlinks_s|title=Tourism Management: Problems and Prospects|first=Bijender K.|last=Punia|date=1 January 1994|publisher=APH Publishing|accessdate=14 September 2016|via=Google Books}} in [[Himachal Pradesh]] cities of Rewalsar, Shimla, Mandi and Prashar Lakes.{{cite web|url= http://www.traveladda.com/north_india/himachal_pradesh/fairs_and_festivals/baisakhi_festival.html |title=Baisakhi Festival|publisher=|accessdate=14 September 2016}} {{clear}} ==Hinduism== {{Hinduism}} [[File:Ganges at Haridwar, Uttarakhand.jpg|thumb|left|Bathing in rivers is a Vaisakhi tradition.]] The first day of Vaisakh marks the traditional solar new year{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=PGXgssv08PgC&pg=PA61 |title=Indian Astronomy: An Introduction|first=S. Balachandra|last=Rao|date=1 January 2000|publisher=Universities Press|accessdate=14 September 2016|via=Google Books}}Tribune 15 April 2011 Baisakhi fervour at Haridwar Lakhs take dip in holy Ganga [http://www.tribuneindia.com/2011/20110415/dplus.htm#1] and it is an ancient festival that predates the founding of Sikhism. The harvest is complete and crops ready to sell, representing a time of plenty for the farmers. Fairs and special thanksgiving pujas (prayers) are common in the Hindu tradition.{{cite book|author=Robin Rinehart|title=Contemporary Hinduism: Ritual, Culture, and Practice|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hMPYnfS_R90C&pg=PA139|year=2004|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-57607-905-8|page=139}} The first day of Vaisakh marks the solar new year.{{cite web |title= BBC – Religion: Hinduism – Vaisakhi|publisher=[[BBC]]|url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/religion/religions/hinduism/holydays/vaisakhi.shtml |accessdate=22 January 2012}} It is the New Year's Day for Hindus in [[Tamil Nadu]], [[Kerala]], [[Odisha]], [[West Bengal]], [[Assam]], [[Bihar]], [[Uttrakhand]], [[Uttar Pradesh]], [[Himachal Pradesh]], [[Haryana]], [[Punjab, India|Punjab]]Crump, William D. (2014) Encyclopedia of New Year's Holidays Worldwide. McFarland [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=cDTfCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA114&dq=vaisakhi+punjabi+hindu+new+year&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwijseXUpvvSAhWrC8AKHS2cDXsQ6AEIKjAD#v=onepage&q=vaisakhi%20punjabi%20hindu%20new%20year&f=false] and other parts of India. However, this is not the universal new year for all Hindus. For some, such as those in and near Gujarat, the new year festivities coincide with the five day [[Diwali]] festival. For others, the new year falls on [[Ugadi]], [[Gudi Padwa]] and [[Cheti Chand]], which falls a few weeks earlier.{{cite book|author1=Karen Pechilis| author2=Selva J. Raj|title= South Asian Religions: Tradition and Today|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=kaubzRxh-U0C&pg=PA48| year=2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0-415-44851-2|pages=48–49}}{{cite book|author=Mark-Anthony Falzon|title=Cosmopolitan Connections: The Sindhi Diaspora, 1860–2000|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ljbS-I5Y8WMC&pg=PA62|year=2004|publisher=BRILL|isbn=90-04-14008-5|page=62}} [[File:4 girls celebrating Assamese Bihu.jpg|thumb|left |Celebrating Baisakhi Bihu in Assam.]] It is regionally known by many names among the Hindus, though the festivities and its significance is similar. It is celebrated by Hindus bathing in sacred rivers, as they believe that river goddess Ganges descended to earth on Vaisakhi.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=5kl0DYIjUPgC&pg=PA81 |title=The Illustrated Encyclopedia of Hinduism: A-M|first=James G.|last=Lochtefeld|date=1 January 2002|publisher=The Rosen Publishing Group|accessdate=14 September 2016|via=Google Books}} Some rivers considered particularly sacred include the Ganges, Jhelum and Kaveri. Hindus visit temples, meet friends and party over festive foods. Vaisakhi coincides with the festival of '[[Vishu]]' celebrated in [[Kerala]] a day after Vaisakhi. The festivities include fireworks, shopping for new clothes and interesting displays called 'Vishu Kani'. Hindus make arrangements of flowers, grains, fruits which friends and family visit to admire as "lucky sight" (''Vishukkani''). Giving gifts to friends and loved ones, as well as alms to the needy are a tradition of Kerala Hindus on this festive day. Vaisakhi is celebrated as Pohela Boishakh in West Bengal and [[Bohag Bihu|Bahag Bihu]] in [[Assam]], but typically one or two days after Vaisakhi.{{cite web |url=http://aghr.cag.gov.in/holidays.pdf |title=2017 Official Central Government Holiday Calendar |accessdate=4 March 2017 |publisher = Government of India}} ===Regional variations=== [[File:Mathapoo vishu.jpg|thumb|Some Indians mark their traditional new year with fireworks.]] The following is a list of new year festivals:Crump, William D. (2014), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=cDTfCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA114 Encyclopedia of New Year's Holidays Worldwide], MacFarland, page 114 * ''Bikhu'' or ''Bikhauti'' in the [[Kumaon division|Kumaon]] region of [[Uttarakhand]], India * ''[[Bisu (festival)|Bisu]]'' – Tulu New Year Day amongst the [[Tulu people]] in India * ''[[Bohag Bihu|Rongali Bihu]]'' in [[Assam]], India * ''[[Kodava people|Edmyaar 1 (Bisu Changrandi)]]'' – [[Kodava people|Kodava]] New Year. * ''[[Vishuva Sankranti|Maha Vishuva Sankranti]]'' (or Pana Sankranti) in [[Odisha]], India * ''JurShital'' (New Year) in [[History of Mithila|Mithila]] (parts of [[Nepal]] and [[Bihar]], India) * ''Naba Barsha'' or ''[[Pohela Boishakh]]'' in [[West Bengal]] and [[Tripura]], India, [[Nepal]] and [[Bangladesh]] * ''[[Ugadi]]'' in [[Andhra Pradesh]], [[Karnataka]] and [[Telangana]], India * ''[[Puthandu]]'' in [[Tamil Nadu]], India * ''[[Vishu]]'' in [[Kerala]], India The new year falls on or about the same day every year for many Buddhist communities in parts of South and Southeast Asia. This is likely an influence of their shared culture in the 1st millennium CE. Some examples include: * ''[[Bikram Samwat]]'' / ''Vaishak Ek'' in [[Nepal]] * ''[[Sinhalese New Year|Aluth Avuruthu]]'' in [[Sri Lanka]].{{cite book|author=Peter Reeves|title=The Encyclopedia of the Sri Lankan Diaspora |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4N5UAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA174 |year=2014|publisher=Didier Millet|isbn=978-981-4260-83-1|page=174}} * ''[[Songkran (Thailand)|Songkran]]'' in [[Thailand]] * ''[[Cambodian New Year|Chol Chnam Thmey]]'' in [[Cambodia]] * ''[[Songkran (Lao)|Pii Mai Lao]]'' in [[Laos]] * ''[[Thingyan]]'' in [[Myanmar]] ====Bikhoti festival==== The Bikhoti Festival of [[Uttrakhand]] involves people taking a dip in holy rivers. A popular custom involves beating symbolic stones representing demons with sticks. The fair is celebrated in various major centres including Sealdah, Bageshwar and Dwarahat and involves much singing and dancing, accompanied by local drums and other instruments.[http://www.edgeofindia.com/locations/uttarakhand/bageshwar/when-to-go/festivals_culture.aspx Festivals and Culture] ====Vishu==== [[File:Vishukani.jpg|thumb|left|A Vishukkani tray before Krishna (Vishnu), a Kerala Hindu tradition]] Vishu is the Hindu new year festival celebrated on the same day as Vaisakhi in the Indian state of [[Kerala]], and falls on the first day of Malayali month called Medam.[https://kerala.gov.in/major-festivals Major festivals of Kerala], Government of Kerala (2016){{cite book|author=J. Gordon Melton|title=Religious Celebrations: An Encyclopedia of Holidays, Festivals, Solemn Observances, and Spiritual Commemorations |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lD_2J7W_2hQC&pg=PA633 |year=2011|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-59884-206-7|page=633}} The festival is notable for its solemnity and the general lack of pomp and show that characterize other Hindu festivals of Kerala such as [[Onam]].{{cite book| author=Maithily Jagannathan|title=South Indian Hindu Festivals and Traditions|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xcIrkKUJH9QC|year = 2005|publisher = Abhinav Publications|isbn= 978-81-7017-415-8|pages=76–77}} The festival is marked by family time, preparing colorful auspicious items and viewing these as the first thing on the Vishu day. In particular, Malayali Hindus seek to view the golden blossoms of the Indian laburnum (''Kani Konna''), money or silver items (''Vishukkaineetam''), and rice. The day also attracts firework play by children,{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Thiruvananthapuram/city-celebrates-vishu/article399057.ece |title=City celebrates Vishu |publisher=The Hindu |date=2010-04-16 |accessdate=2013-09-27}} wearing new clothes (''Puthukodi'') and the eating a special meal called ''[[Sadya]]'', which is a mix of salty, sweet, sour and bitter items.{{cite web|url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/metroplus/when-the-laburnum-blooms/article1696077.ece |title=When the Laburnum blooms |publisher=The Hindu |date=2011-04-14 |accessdate=2013-09-27}} The Vishu arrangement typically includes an image of [[Vishnu]], typically as [[Krishna]]. People also visit temples on the day.{{cite book|author=Roshen Dalal|title=Hinduism: An Alphabetical Guide|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DH0vmD8ghdMC&pg=PA461|year=2010|publisher=Penguin Books|isbn=978-0-14-341421-6|page=461}} ====Bohag Bihu==== [[File:Dhuliya perfroming in a open stage bihu.JPG|thumb|Festive Bihu with Dhuliya is an Assamese Hindu tradition on this day.]] Bohag Bihu or Rangali Bihu marks the beginning of the Assamese New Year on 13 April. It is celebrated for seven days Vishuva Sankranti (Mesha Sankranti) of the month of Vaisakh or locally 'Bohag' (Bhaskar Calendar). The three primary types of Bihu are Rongali Bihu, Kongali Bihu, and Bhogali Bihu. Each festival historically recognizes a different agricultural cycle of the paddy crops. During Rangali Bihu there are 7 pinnacle phases: 'Chot', 'Raati', 'Goru', 'Manuh', 'Kutum', 'Mela' and 'Chera'.{{citation needed|date=March 2017}} ====Maha Vishuva Sankranti==== [[Maha Vishuva Sankranti]] marks the Oriya new year in [[Odisha]]. Celebrations include various types of folk and classical dances, such as the Shiva-related [[Chhau dance]].{{cite book|author=Sitakant Mahapatra|title=Chhau Dance of Mayurbhanj|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4VHkAAAAMAAJ |year=1993|publisher=Vidyapuri|page=86}} ====Pahela Baishakh==== {{main article|Pohela Boishakh}} [[File:Colors of Celebration!-4.JPG|thumb|Pohela Boishakh celebrations in Dhaka, Bangladesh.]] The Bengali new year is celebrated as Pahela Baishakh on 14 April every year, and a festive [[Mangal Shobhajatra]], started by students of Dhaka University in Bangladesh in 1989,{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefinancialexpress-bd.com/2017/04/14/66874/%27Mongol-Shobhajatra%27-parades-city-streets|title='Mongol Shobhajatra' parades city streets|website=The Financial Express Online Version|access-date=2017-04-16}} is organized in West Bengal, Tripura and Bangladesh. This celebration was listed in 2016 by the [[UNESCO]] as a cultural heritage of humanity.[http://www.unesco.org/culture/ich/en/RL/mangal-shobhajatra-on-pahela-baishakh-01091 Mangal Shobhajatra on Pahela Baishakh], UNESCO{{Cite news|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/frontpage/unesco-cultural-heritage-list-adds-mangal-shobhajatra-1323331|title=Unesco lists Mangal Shobhajatra as cultural heritage|date=2016-12-01|work=The Daily Star|access-date=2017-04-16|language=en}} The festival is celebrated as a national holiday in [[Bangladesh]]. Also spelled Pohela Boishakh is also known as Nobo Barsho as it is the first day of the Bengali month of Bongabdo. Fairs are organised to celebrate the event which provide entertainment including the presentation of folk songs.{{citation needed|date=March 2017}} ====Puthandu==== Puthandu, also known as ''Puthuvarusham'' or ''Tamil New Year'', is the first day of the month ''Chithirai'' on the [[Tamil calendar]].{{cite book|author=Roshen Dalal|title=Hinduism: An Alphabetical Guide|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DH0vmD8ghdMC |year=2010|publisher=Penguin Books|isbn=978-0-14-341421-6|page=406}}{{cite book|author=J. Gordon Melton|title=Religious Celebrations: An Encyclopedia of Holidays, Festivals, Solemn Observances, and Spiritual Commemorations |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lD_2J7W_2hQC&pg=PA633|year=2011|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=978-1-59884-206-7|page=633}} On this day, Tamil people greet each other by saying "Puttāṇṭu vāḻttukkaḷ!" or "Iṉiya puttāṇṭu nalvāḻttukkaḷ!", which is equivalent to "Happy new year".{{cite book|author=William D. Crump|title=Encyclopedia of New Year's Holidays Worldwide |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cDTfCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA220 |year=2014|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-9545-0|page=220}} The day is observed as a family time. Households clean up the house, prepare a tray with fruits, flowers and auspicious items, light up the family [[Puja (Hinduism)|Puja]] altar and visit their local temples. People wear new clothes and youngster go to elders to pay respects and seek their blessings, then the family sits down to a vegetarian feast.{{cite book|author=Samuel S. Dhoraisingam|title=Peranakan Indians of Singapore and Melaka |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QHwcAgAAQBAJ |year=2006|publisher=Institute of Southeast Asian Studies|isbn=978-981-230-346-2|page=38}} ====Jurshital in Bihar==== In the Mithal region of [[Bihar]] and [[Nepal]], the new year is celebrated as Jurshital.Hari Bansh Jha (1993) The terai community and national integration in Nepal.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=JShuAAAAMAAJ&q=JurShital+new+year&dq=JurShital+new+year&hl=en&sa=X&ei=yFYzVZaiD5LaaPLFgCg&ved=0CCYQ6AEwAQ] It is traditional to use lotus leaves to serve [[sattu]] (powdered meal derived from grains of red gram and jau (Hordeum vulgare) and other ingredients) to the family members.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ugVFAQAAIAAJ&q=Jurshital&dq=Jurshital&hl=en&sa=X&ei=J6MzVYuBGtOWavbCgIgO&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAw Ethnobotany (2002)Aavishkar Publishers] ==Sikh celebrations outside India== ==={{PAK}}=== Pakistan has many sites that are of historic importance to the Sikh faith, such as the birth place of Guru Nanak. These sites attract pilgrims from India and abroad every year on Vaisakhi.[https://www.dawn.com/news/1176098 Glare and galore at Baisakhi festival], The Dawn, Pakistan (15 April 2015)[http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/vaisakhi-2015-sikh-devotees-celebrate-major-festival-india-pakistan-photos-1496358 Vaisakhi 2015: Sikh devotees celebrate major festival in India and Pakistan], David Sims, International Business Times Pakistan used to have many more Sikhs, but a vast majority moved to India during the 1947 India-Pakistan partition. Contemporary Pakistan has about 20,000 Sikhs in a total population of about 200 million Pakistanis, or about 0.01%.Ary News 17 April 2015 Sikh pligrims gather in Pakistan for Vaisakhi festival [http://arynews.tv/en/sikh-pligrims-gather-in-pakistan-for-vaisakhi-festival/] These Sikhs, and thousands more who arrive from other parts of the world for pilgrimage, observe Vaisakhi in [[Punjab, Pakistan|Western Punjab]] (Pakistan) with festivities centered on the [[Panja Sahib]] complex in [[Hasan Abdal]], [[Gurudwara]]s in [[Nankana Sahib]], and in various historical sites in [[Lahore]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thaindian.com/newsportal/world-news/sikhs-throng-pakistan-shrine-for-baisakhi_10037124.html|title=Sikh throng Pakistan shrine for Vaisakhi|author=Muhammad Najeeb Hasan Abdal|date=12 April 2008|work=Thaindian News|publisher=www.thaindian.com|accessdate=22 January 2012}}{{refn|group=note|On 8 April 2016, Punjabi Parchar at Alhamra (Lahore) organised a show called Visakhi mela, where the speakers pledged to "continue our struggle to keep the Punjabi culture alive" in Pakistan through events such as Visakhi Mela.Pakistan Today (8 April 2016) [http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2016/04/08/promoting-peace-with-punjabi-at-visakhi-mela/ Punjabi Parchar spreads colours of love at Visakhi Mela] Elsewhere Besakhi fairs or melas are held in various places including [[Eminabad]][https://www.dawn.com/news/953015 A fair dedicated to animal lovers (20.04.2009) Dawn] and [[Dera Ghazi Khan]].Agnes Ziegler, Akhtar Mummunka (2006) The final Frontier: unique photographs of Pakistan. Sang-e-Meel Publications [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=AhNuAAAAMAAJ&q=besakhi+mela+sakhi&dq=besakhi+mela+sakhi&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiQ67W705zTAhVrKsAKHZ5iBJIQ6AEIHDAA]}} According to Aziz-ud-din Ahmed, [[Lahore]] used to have Baisakhi Mela after the harvesting of the wheat crop in April. However, adds Ahmed, the city started losing its cultural vibrancy in 1970s after Zia-ul-Haq came to power, and in recent years "the [[Pakistan Muslim League (N)]] government in Punjab banned kite flying through an official edict more under the pressure of those who want a puritanical version of Islam to be practiced in the name of religion than anything else".[http://www.pakistantoday.com.pk/2015/02/21/cultural-decline-in-lahore/ Cultural Decline in Pakistan], Pakistan Today, Aziz-ud-din Ahmed (21 February 2015) Unlike the Indian state of Punjab that recognizes the Vaisakhi Sikh festival as an official holiday,[http://punjab.gov.in/list-of-holidays Official Holidays], Government of Punjab, India (2016) the festival is not an official holiday in Punjab or Sindh provinces of Pakistan where Islamic holidays are officially recognized instead.[http://www.schools.punjab.gov.pk/system/files/Notification_2.pdf Official Holidays 2016], Government of Punjab – Pakistan (2016)[http://www.kmc.gos.pk/Contents.aspx?id=48 Official Holidays 2016], Karachi Metropolitan, Sindh, Pakistan ==={{CAN}}=== In the [[British Columbia|Province of British Columbia]], large, local Sikh communities in the cities of [[Vancouver, British Columbia|Vancouver]], [[Abbotsford, British Columbia|Abbotsford]], and [[Surrey, British Columbia|Surrey]] hold their annual Vaisakhi celebrations in April,Global News 12 April 2015 Vaisakhi celebrated at parade in south Vancouver [http://globalnews.ca/news/1934020/vaisakhi-celebrated-at-parade-in-south-vancouver/] which include two [[Nagar Kirtan]] (parades). The Vancouver parade starts at Ross Street TempleRoss Street Temple [http://kdsross.com/] and makes its way through the traditional Punjabi market in South Vancouver.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/thousands-brighten-vancouver-streets-to-mark-vaisakhi-1.4620393|title=Thousands brighten Vancouver streets to mark Vaisakhi|newspaper=CBC News|accessdate=24 April 2018}} One week later, the festival in Surrey is one of the largest such celebrations outside of India, having attracted over 200,000 people in 2014VancouverDesi.com 14 April 2015 What you need to know about the Vaisakhi parade [http://www.vancouverdesi.com/news/nridiaspora/what-you-need-to-know-about-the-vaisakhi-parade/865596/], over 350,000 in 2015, and approached 400,000 in 2016. The 2017 attendance in Surrey reportedly topped 400,000, causing organizers to consider future distribution of the festival over several days and local cities, particularly in areas of economic disadvantage which would benefit from the generous charitable efforts seen during Vaisakhi celebrations.{{cite web|url=http://vancouversun.com/news/local-news/0423-surrey-vaisakhi|title=Surrey's Vaisakhi parade draws record attendance in massive celebration of diversity and inclusion|newspaper=Vancouver Sun|accessdate=21 April 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/up-to-400k-people-expected-to-attend-2017-surrey-vaisakhi-parade-1.4080812|title=Up to 400K people expected to attend 2017 Surrey Vaisakhi parade|newspaper=CBC News|accessdate=21 April 2017}} Record attendance was again experienced in April, 2018 in the 20th annual Surrey Vaisakhi parade, with the [[RCMP]] officially estimating the crowd at over half a million people in a city with a 2016 census population of 517,887.{{cite web|url=https://www.northdeltareporter.com/news/surreys-vaisakhi-parade-biggest-ever/|title=Surrey’s Vaisakhi parade biggest ever|newspaper=North Delta Reporter|accessdate=24 April 2018}} Starting at the Gurdwara Dashmesh Darbar Temple (12885 85th Avenue in Surrey), the parade features a variety of floats, community groups, free food, live music and dancers and performers, and travels along 124th Street, turns left onto 75th Avenue, continues on 76th Avenue, onto 128th Street, then back to the Temple.{{cite web|url=http://www.surreyvaisakhiparade.com/files/parade-map.php|title=Surrey Vaisakhi Parade Map|accessdate=24 April 2018}} [[Kelowna]]'s annual Vaisakhi parade is held a week after Surrey's parade each year and begins and ends at the Sikh Temple on Rutland Road.{{cite web|url=https://www.castanet.net/edition/news-story-224630-1-.htm#224630|title=Vaisakhi Parade Saturday|newspaper=Castanet|accessdate=25 April 2018}} [[Greater Victoria|Victoria]]'s all-day Vaisakhi celebration features a parade that begins and ends at Gurdwara Singh Sabha, 470 Cecelia Road. The 2018 celebrations on 29 April will be the first held in Victoria in over 100 years.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/vaisakhi-victoria-parade-1.4635163|title=After 100 years, Vaisakhi returns to Victoria|newspaper=CBC|accessdate=28 April 2018}} In the [[Alberta|Province of Alberta]], the [[Edmonton]] Vaisakhi parade is held in May and travels between the Gurdwara Singh Sabha (4504 Millwoods Road S) & Gurdwara Millwoods (2606 Millwoods Road E) temples.{{cite web|url=http://www.vaisakhiparade.com|title=Vaisakhi 2018|accessdate=24 April 2018}} In the [[Nova Scotia|Province of Nova Scotia]], the [[Halifax, Nova Scotia|Halifax]]-based Maritime Sikh Society holds Vaisakhi celebrations in April featuring [[Sikh music|Shabad Kirtan]] performed by professional ragis (musicians).{{cite web|url=http://maritimesikhsociety.com/|title=Maritime Sikh Society - About Us|accessdate=28 April 2018}} In the [[Ontario|Province of Ontario]], the [[Toronto]] Vaisakhi Parade is held in April, starting at the Canadian National Exhibition grounds and traveling east to Toronto City Hall, finishing almost three hours later. Following the parade, dignitaries address the gathering until late afternoon.{{cite web|url=https://www.toronto.com/events/khalsa-day-parade/|title=Khalsa Day Parade Celebrate the founding of the Sikh community. at Better Living Centre|accessdate=24 April 2018}} In the city of [[Malton, Mississauga|Malton]], a three-hour Nagar Kirtan parade winds from Morning Star, Goreway, Derry Rd, & Airport Rd to Malton Gurdwara Sahib. In the city of [[Brampton]], the Gurudwara Sikh Sangat temple and Gobind Sarvar Gurmat School hold Vaisakhi cultural events such as yoga, pagh (turban) tying, storytelling, and food fairs.{{cite web|url=http://www.gobindsarvarbrampton.com/school/yolo-event/vaisakhi-cultural-food-fair/|title=Vaisakhi Cultural Food Fair|accessdate=24 April 2018}} In the [[Saskatchewan|Province of Saskatchewan]], the [[Saskatoon]] Vaisakhi parade is held in May, starting and ending at the Gurudwara Sahib Temple at 331 Lowe Road.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/saskatoon/sikh-parade-saskatoon-crowd-1.4134571|title=1st-ever Saskatoon Sikh Parade was so busy it spurred a traffic advisory|accessdate=28 April 2018}} ==={{UK}}=== The [[United Kingdom]] has a large Sikh community originating from the Indian sub-continent, [[East Africa]]S. K. Rait (2005) Sikh Women in England: Their Religious and Cultural Beliefs and Social Practices [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=hRfkTq1ykSIC&dq=sikhs+in+england&source=gbs_navlinks_s] and [[Afghanistan]]. The largest concentrations of [[Sikhs]] in the UK are to be found in the West Midlands (especially [[Birmingham]] and [[Wolverhampton]]) and [[London]].Amarjeet Singh (2014) Indian Diaspora: Voices of Grandparents and Grandparenting [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=vo_HBAAAQBAJ&dq=largest+sikh+community+in+england+birmingham&source=gbs_navlinks_s] The Southall [[Nagar Kirtan]] is held on a Sunday a week or two before Vaisakhi. The Birmingham [[Nagar Kirtan]] is held in late April in association with Birmingham City Council,{{cite web|url=http://www.birmingham.gov.uk/vaisakhi|title=Things to do – Birmingham City Council|first=Birmingham City|last=Council|publisher=|accessdate=14 September 2016}} and is an annual event attracting thousands of people which commences with two separate nagar kirtans setting off from [[gurdwara]]s in the city and culminating in the Vaisakhi [[Mela]] at Handsworth Park.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-birmingham-17805970|accessdate=10 May 2012|newspaper=BBC News|date=22 April 2012|title=Thousands join Sikh Vaisakhi celebrations in Birmingham}} ==={{USA}}=== Amongst Sikh populations in the [[United States]], there is usually a parade commemorating the Vaisakhi celebration. In [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]]{{cite web|url=http://www.nycsikhdayparade.com/|title=Annual NYC Sikh Day Parade|author=|date=30 April 2012|publisher=www.nycsikhdayparade.com|accessdate=22 January 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322192021/http://www.nycsikhdayparade.com/|archivedate=22 March 2012|df=}} people come out to do "[[Selfless service|Seva]]" (selfless service) such as giving out free food, and completing any other labor that needs to be done. In [[Los Angeles, California]], the local Sikh community consisting of many [[gurdwara]]s{{cite web|url=http://www.gururamdasashram.org/baisakhi|title=Baisakhi – Guru Ram Das Ashram|publisher=|accessdate=14 September 2016}} holds a full day [[Kirtan]] (spiritual music) program followed by a parade. ==={{MYS}}=== The Sikh community, a subgroup of the [[Malaysian Indian]] ethnic minority race, is an [[ethnoreligious]] minority in Malaysia, which is why Vaisakhi is not a public holiday. However, in line with the government's efforts to promote integration among the country's different ethnic and religious groups, the prime minister, [[Najib Razak]] has announced that beginning 2013, all government servants from the Sikh [[Malaysian Indian]] community will be given a day off on Vaisakhi Day.{{cite news|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2012/5/8/nation/11249703&sec=nation|title=Sikh civil servants get Vaisakhi holiday|accessdate=15 February 2013|newspaper=The Star Online|date=8 May 2012}} Vaisakhi 'open houses' are also held across the country during the day of the festival, or the closest weekend to it. ==Spelling of Vaisakhi== The spelling varies with region. In Punjab region, Vaisakhi is common, while in the [[Doabi]] and [[Malwi dialect|Malwai]] regions, it is common for speakers to substitute a "B" for a "V".{{Cite web |url=http://punjabrevenue.nic.in/gaz_gdr5.htm |title=Archived copy |access-date=26 November 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304123940/http://punjabrevenue.nic.in/gaz_gdr5.htm |archive-date=4 March 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} Therefore, the spelling used is dependent on the dialect of the writer. == Photo gallery == File:Vaisakhi1.jpg|A depiction of [[Guru Gobind Singh]] initiating the first five members of the [[Khalsa]] File:Panj Pyare, leading a procession.jpg|The [[Panj Pyare]] at Vaisakhi 2007 [[Wolverhampton]], UK File:Vaisakhi 2012 London - 22.jpg|Vaisakhi at [[Trafalgar Square]], London File:Vaisakhi 2012 London - 21.jpg|Vaisakhi 2012 at [[Trafalgar Square]], London File:Vaisakhi 2012 London - 23.jpg|Vaisakhi 2012 at [[Trafalgar Square]], London File:Vaisakhi Sikh festival in Birmingham 2013.jpg|Vaisakhi celebrations in Birmingham File:Panj Pyare, leading a procession.jpg|The [[Panj Pyare]] at Vaisakhi 2007 [[Wolverhampton]], UK File:Dessert on tray.jpg|[[Jalebi]]yan being served at Vaisakhi Day, April 11, 2009, [[Vancouver]] Canada File:Airplane-mobile.jpg|2009 [[Vancouver]] Sikh Vaisakhi parade File:Sikh Motorcycle Club at Vaisakhi.jpg|Sikh Motorcycle Club at Vaisakhi 2007 [[Vancouver, British Columbia]], Canada File:Sikh Motorcycle Club at Vaisakhi.jpg|Sikh Motorcycle Club at Vaisakhi 2007 [[Vancouver, British Columbia]], Canada File:Vaisakhi fair mela in Surrey Canada.jpg|Vaisakhi festival in Surrey, BC, Canada File:Vaisakhi Day Celebration (8651688584).jpg|A band performs at Vaisakhi day celebrations in Kuala Lumpur (2013) ==Notes== {{reflist|group=note}} ==References== {{Reflist|25em}} {{Punjabi fairs and festivals}} {{Punjab, India}} {{Sikhism}} {{HinduFestivals}} {{Hindudharma}} [[Category:Sikh festivals]] [[Category:New Year in Pakistan]] [[Category:New Year in India]] [[Category:Religious festivals in India]] [[Category:Punjabi festivals]] [[Category:Festivals in Punjab, Pakistan]] [[Category:Religious festivals in Pakistan]] [[Category:Non-Gregorian April observances]] [[Category:Observances on non-Gregorian calendars]] [[Category:Harvest festivals]] [[Category:Spring (season) events in Pakistan]]

page.title: Wedding of Prince Philippe and Mathilde d'Udekem d'Acoz

revision.text:
{{Infobox event | image = Dual Cypher of Prince Philippe and Princess Mathilde of Belgium.svg | image_size = 175px | image_alt = | caption = | date = {{start date|4 December 1999}} | venue = [[Brussels Town Hall]] and [[St. Michael and St. Gudula Cathedral|Cathedral of Saint Michel]] | location = [[Brussels]], Belgium | participants = [[Philippe of Belgium|Prince Philippe, Duke of Brabant]]
[[Queen Mathilde of Belgium|''Jonkvrouw'' Mathilde d'Udekem d'Acoz]] }} The '''wedding of Prince Philippe, Duke of Brabant, and Mathilde d'Udekem d'Acoz''' took place on 4 December 1999 in [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]]. The civil proceedings were conducted at [[Brussels Town Hall]] while the religious ceremony took place at the [[St. Michael and St. Gudula Cathedral|Cathedral of Saint Michel]]. The wedding has been described as the social event of the decade within Belgium{{cite encyclopedia |last=Langeneckert |first=Sandra |encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Britannica |title=Prince and Princess of Belgium Philippe and Mathilde |url=http://www.britannica.com/biography/Philippe-and-Mathilde-Prince-and-Princess-of-Belgium |access-date=28 March 2016 |publisher=britannica.com }} and it was the last royal wedding of the second millennium.{{cite news |last=Collins |first=Glenn |date=7 September 2000 |title=For This Couple, The Royal Tour Starts Here; Belgian Prince and Princess Have New York in Sight |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/09/07/nyregion/for-this-couple-royal-tour-starts-here-belgian-prince-princess-have-new-york.html?pagewanted=all |newspaper=New York Times |access-date=13 April 2016 }} ==The bride and groom== The groom, then [[Philippe of Belgium|Philippe]], [[Duke of Brabant]], is the eldest son of [[Albert II of Belgium|King Albert II]] and [[Queen Paola of Belgium|Queen Paola]].{{cite web |url=https://www.monarchie.be/en/royal-family/the-king |title=The King |author= |website=The Belgian Monarchy |publisher=Federal Public Department for Information and Communication Technology |access-date=13 April 2016 }} The bride, [[Queen Mathilde of Belgium|Mathilde d'Udekem d'Acoz]] is the daughter of [[Patrick d'Udekem d'Acoz]], a Belgian [[nobility|nobleman]] and [[Anna Maria Komorowska]], a descendant of [[Poles|Polish]] [[szlachta|noble families]] such as the Princes [[Sapieha]] and Counts [[Komorowski (Korczak) family|Komorowski]].{{cite web |url=http://www.monarquiaconfidencial.com/belgica/Fallece-Patrick-princesa-Matilde-Belgica_0_1038496147.html |title=Fallece a los 72 años Patrick d’Udekem d’Acoz, padre de la princesa Matilde de Bélgica |last=Rey y Cabieses |first=Amadeo-Martín |date=27 September 2008 |website=monarquiaconfidencial.com |language=Spanish |trans-title=Patrick d'Udekem d'Acoz, father of Princess Mathilde of Belgium, dies at 72 |access-date=13 April 2016}} After the wedding, Mathilde became Duchess of Brabant and a Princess of Belgium on 8 November 1999 (published on 13 November 1999 and effective from 4 December 1999). In 2013 Philippe and Mathilde became the King and Queen of the Belgians. Mathilde is the first Belgian born queen in the country's history.{{cite encyclopedia |author= |encyclopedia=Encyclopædia Britannica |title=Mathilde, queen of Belgium |url=http://www.britannica.com/biography/Mathilde-queen-of-Belgium |access-date=13 April 2016 |publisher=britannica.com }} ==Wedding events== {{ external media | float =right | width =200px | image1 =[http://www.gettyimages.fr/detail/photo-d'actualit%C3%A9/marriage-of-prince-philippe-of-belgium-with-mathilde-photo-dactualit%C3%A9/160749122 Philippe and Mathilde exiting the Cathedral of Saint Michel] }} The first of the day's main events took place in the Gothic setting of [[Brussels Town Hall]] where Philippe and Mathilde contracted a [[civil marriage]] in the French, Flemish Dutch and German languages.{{cite news |author= |title=Royal wedding grips Belgium |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/549681.stm |newspaper=BBC News |date=4 December 1999 |access-date=29 March 2016 }} Mathilde's bridal gown was designed by [[Edouard Vermeulen]]. Philippe wore the uniform of a [[Belgian Air Force]] [[Colonel (Belgium)|colonel]].{{cite web |url=http://www.nettyroyal.nl/en/non_pro/specials_weddings_1999_philippe_mathilde.html |title=The wedding of the Duke of Brabant and Jonkvrouw Mathilde d'Udekem d'Acoz |last1=Leistra |first1=Netty |date=3 December 2013 |website=nettyroyal.nl |access-date=14 April 2016 }}Prince Philippe [http://www.gettyimages.co.nz/detail/news-photo/wedding-of-prince-philippe-of-belgium-and-mathilde-dudekem-news-photo/154377528 gets married] in his uniform of Colonel of the Belgian Air Force Thereafter the couple traveled to the nearby [[St. Michael and St. Gudula Cathedral|Cathedral of Saint Michel]] to marry according to the rites of the Roman Catholic Church. An evening reception took place in the [[Chateau de Laeken]], a royal residence. ==Popular reactions and effects== The run up to the wedding was said to have led to widespread feelings of positive sentiment in Belgium,{{cite magazine |author= |title=Belgium's Prenuptial Glow |magazine=[[Business Week]] |location=New York |publisher=McGraw-Hill |publication-date=6 December 1999 |issue=3658-3661 |pages=7, 8 }} with the potential for greater unity between the country's Flemish-speaking north and French-speaking south.{{cite news |last=James |first=Barry |date=25 October 1999 |title=A Boon for Unity?/ Smiles Almost All Around : For Belgium, Crown Prince's Wedding Comes at Opportune Time |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/10/25/news/25iht-belgium.2.t.html |newspaper=New York Times |access-date=13 April 2016 }} Around 50,000 people lined the streets of Brussels on the occasion of Philippe and Mathilde's wedding.{{cite book |author= |title=Political Risk Yearbook: West Europe |volume= 6 |location= |publisher=Political Risk Services Group |page=53 |date=2001 |isbn=}} As many as 200,000 people had been expected but the lower numbers were perhaps on account of the bitterly cold weather on the day. After the wedding some popular culture academics commented that the wedding had had a unifying effect on the Belgian people as well as marking a new phase of positivity in the country.{{cite book |last1=Blain |first1=Neil |last2=O'Donnell |first2=Hugh |date=2003 |title=Media, Monarchy and Power |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pRU7ax9dXPYC&pg=PT350&lpg=PT350 |publisher=Intellect Books |isbn=9781841500430}} The BBC however reported that academics and political commentators in Belgium deemed that the national rift was too great for the wedding to have much effect. ==Guests== ===Relatives of the Groom=== ====Belgian Royal Family==== * [[Albert II of Belgium|The King]] and [[Queen Paola of Belgium|Queen of Belgium]], ''the groom's parents'' ** [[Princess Astrid of Belgium, Archduchess of Austria-Este|The Archduchess]] and [[Prince Lorenz of Belgium, Archduke of Austria-Este|Archduke of Austria-Este]], ''the groom's sister and her husband'' *** [[Prince Amedeo of Belgium, Archduke of Austria-Este]], ''the groom's nephew'' *** [[Princess Maria Laura of Belgium, Archduchess of Austria-Este]], ''the groom's niece'' *** [[Prince Joachim of Belgium, Archduke of Austria-Este]], ''the groom's nephew'' *** [[Princess Luisa Maria of Belgium, Archduchess of Austria-Este]], ''the groom's niece'' ** [[Prince Laurent of Belgium]], ''the groom's brother'' * [[Queen Fabiola of Belgium]], ''widow of the groom's uncle [[Baudouin of Belgium|King Baudouin of Belgium]]'' * [[Prince Alexandre of Belgium|Prince Alexandre]] and [[Princess Léa of Belgium]], ''the groom's uncle and his wife'' * [[Princess Marie-Esméralda of Belgium|Princess Marie-Esméralda of Belgium]] and [[Salvador Moncada]], ''the groom's aunt and her husband'' ====Di Calabria family==== * Prince Fabrizio and Donna Luisa Ruffo di Calabria ** Prince Fulco and Princess Melba Ruffo di Calabria ** Prince Augusto Ruffo di Calabria ** Princess Irma Ruffo di Calabria ** Prince Alessandro Ruffo di Calabria * Don Antonello and Donna Rosa Maria Ruffo di Calabria ** Don Lucio Ruffo di Calabria ** Donna Claudia Ruffo di Calabria * Flavia Porcari Li Destri * Donna Marielli Ruffo di Calabria ===Relatives of the Bride=== * [[Patrick d'Udekem d'Acoz|Count Patrick]] and [[Anna Maria Komorowska|Countess Anna Maria d’Udekem d’Acoz]], ''the bride's parents'' ** Countess Elisabeth d’Udekem d’Acoz, ''the bride's sister'' ** Countess Hélène d’Udekem d’Acoz, ''the bride's sister'' ** Count Charles-Henri d’Udekem d’Acoz, ''the bride's brother'' * Count Henri d’Udekem d’Acoz * Count Raoul and Countess Francoise d’Udekem d’Acoz * Count Michel and Countess Dominique Komorowski * Countess Marie Komorowski and Gérard Braun * Jean-Michel and Rose Maus de Rolley * Countess Gabrielle Komorowski * Alain and Christine de Brabant * Prince Alexandre Sapieha * Prince Stefan Sapieha ===Foreign royalty=== ====Members of reigning families==== * {{flagicon|Denmark}} [[Margrethe II of revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{unreferenced|date=April 2016}} {{notability|Events|date=April 2016}} {{advert|date=March 2017}} }} {{Infobox convention | name = World Quality Day | image = WQD_2018_logo.png | caption =https://www.quality.org/world-quality-day-2018 | status = Active | genre = Awareness day | venue = Various | country = Various | first = 2008 | last = 2018 | organizer = The [[Chartered Quality Institute]] }} '''World Quality Day''' is celebrated every year around the world in November. The day was designed to increase worldwide awareness of the important contribution that quality makes towards both organisational and national growth, and prosperity.
World Quality Day takes place every year on the second Thursday of November. Businesses across the world take part in a variety of activities such as business-wide seminars, presentations, quizzes and competitions at their workplace. Events are usually organised by quality professionals based within organisations and are designed to spread the ‘importance of quality’ message to non-quality professionals.
According to the [[Chartered Quality Institute]] (CQI), the responsibility of the quality professional can be defined through five main areas – governance, assurance, improvement, leadership and context.
[[File:QP leaflet A3 landscape-2-Resized.jpg|thumb|The competency framework diagram showing the 5 areas of the framework; Leadership, Governance, Assurance, Improvement and context.]]
== World Quality Day 2018 == For 2018, the theme is ‘Quality: A question of trust ’
== Previous years ==
2018: Quality: A question of trust which focuses on reputation and trust.
2017: Celebrating Everyday Leadership which focuses on Quality professionals at all levels displaying leadership behaviours.
2016: Making operational governance count’ which focuses on the impact of failure and how it is putting the reputation of organisations in the private, public, and not-for-profit sectors under the spotlight like never before.
2014: ‘Building a Quality World Together’ which focuses on the impact quality professionals make to an organisation.
2013: ‘Making Collaboration Count’. Designed to reflect the importance of collaborating with colleagues, departments and partner organisations
2012: ‘Quality: Delivering Competitive Advantage’. Derived from the belief that in order to survive during an economic downturn, organisations require a strong competitive advantage, and that quality management and its focus on improving efficiency and productivity can help organisations achieve this.
2011: 'In Pursuit of Excellence’. Recognising that in order to succeed, organisations must continuously strive to improve.
2010: 'Out of the Crisis'. Focused on what a fit organisation looks like and the role that quality management professionals play in facilitating fitness.
2009 Organisations worldwide ran events or participated in one of the specially organised regional events.
2008 Saw the first World Quality Day conference at the Imarsat Conference Centre in London and provided a forum for innovation, inspiration and creative ideas.
==See also== *[[Chartered Quality Institute]] *[[British Quality Foundation]] *[[European Organization for Quality]] *[[International Register of Certificated Auditors]] *[[United Kingdom Accreditation Service]]
==External links== *{{Official website|https://www.quality.org}}
